headline.main: Should the Morning-After Pill Be Sold Over the Counter to People Under 17?

docs.abstract: Student Opinion | Read the related articles and tell us what you think about recent decision by the United States secretary of health.
docs.snippet: Student Opinion | Read the related articles and tell us what you think about recent decision by the United States secretary of health.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States secretary of health publicly overruled the Food and Drug Administration this week, refusing to allow emergency contraception known as the "morning-after pill" to be sold without a prescription to people under 17. (If taken soon after unprotected sex, the pill halves the chances of a pregnancy.)

headline.main: Should the Morning-After Pill Be Sold Over the Counter to People Under 17?

docs.lead_paragraph: Responses to a news article, “F.D.A. Overruled on Availability of After-Sex Pill.”

headline.main: The Decision on the Morning-After Pill
headline.print_headline: The Decision on the Morning-After Pill

docs.snippet: Responses to a news article, “F.D.A. Overruled on Availability of After-Sex Pill.”

docs.lead_paragraph: The decision to restrict emergency contraceptives to girls below the age of 17 without prescription is an example of politics trumping science and sound policy.
docs.abstract: Editorial scores Obama administration's move to overrule decision by Food and Drug Administration to make the so-called morning-after pill available without prescription to girls below the age of 17; holds action is example of politics trumping science and sound policy.
docs.snippet: The decision to restrict emergency contraceptives to girls below the age of 17 without prescription is an example of politics trumping science and sound policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a report issued Wednesday, the Institute of Medicine affirmed some well-known risks but said many others remain unclear.

headline.seo: Panel Finds Few Clear Environmental Links to Breast Cancer
headline.main: Scientific Panel Finds Few Clear Environmental Links to Breast Cancer
headline.print_headline: Panel Finds Few Clear Environmental Links to Breast Cancer

docs.abstract: Exhaustive new report issued by the Institute of Medicine meant to address public fears about possible links between breast cancer and the environment finds evidence strong enough to make only a few firm recommendations, most already known and none with a large proven benefit.
docs.snippet: In a report issued Wednesday, the Institute of Medicine affirmed some well-known risks but said many others remain unclear.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health secretary overruled the Food and Drug Administration’s decision that emergency contraceptives be sold freely over the counter, including to teenagers 16 years old and younger.

headline.seo: Sebelius Overrules F.D.A. on Freer Sale of Emergency Contraceptives
headline.main: Plan to Widen Availability of Morning-After Pill Is Rejected
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Overruled On Availability Of After-Sex Pill

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius overrules the Food and Drug Administration, refusing to allow emergency contraceptives to be sold over the counter, including to young teenagers; it is the first time that the HHS has overruled the FDA and the decision avoids what could have been a bruising political battle over parental control and contraception.
docs.snippet: The health secretary overruled the Food and Drug Administration’s decision that emergency contraceptives be sold freely over the counter, including to teenagers 16 years old and younger.

docs.lead_paragraph: After two floods, Pulling Down the Moon, which offers yoga classes and other services to women undergoing fertility treatments, asks itself whether it should stay or go.

headline.seo: A Business Tries to Decide Whether Its Location Is Perfect, or a Disaster
headline.main: A Business Ponders Whether Its Location Is Perfect, or a Disaster
headline.print_headline: A Business Ponders Whether Its Location Is Perfect, or a Disaster

docs.abstract: Case Study column examines Pulling Down the Moon, which offers yoga classes and other services to women undergoing fertility treatments; notes its Chicago office is reconsidering relocating after flooding.
docs.snippet: After two floods, Pulling Down the Moon, which offers yoga classes and other services to women undergoing fertility treatments, asks itself whether it should stay or go.
